text: Marks a point in a SOP network where intermediate (or expensive) results can be saved to disk and re-used.

If you have complex SOP networks with many nodes (such as large-scale RBD or particle simulations, etc.), you probably want to
break down your network to a few logical units. A Waypoint SOP can represent the end of such a logical unit,
with the additional feature of being able to store it on disk (so it can be reused instead of recalculated).

caching, although the underlining mechanism is similar
    (and obviously the SOP node can be used as a cache). It’s more akin to 'baking' than caching.
Conceptual differences between waypointing and caching
Waypoint: a separator between large logical units

In really complex networks, the entire network consists of usually two or more large logical units.
    A waypoint marks the end of such a unit ('compartment').

When the user finished working on (or modifying) a large logical block of SOP nodes, she marks it
    by 'rendering' the related waypoint (possibly some downstream waypoints, too). Although this has
    to be done manually, this level of caretaking always has to happen in practice
    (it’s also a good opportunity to compare with an earlier on-disk version, etc.)
Caching is (supposed to be) automatic, waypointing is not.

A consequence of manual updating is that it is easy for the geometry on disk to get out of
    sync with the state of the SOP network. This can be less of a problem if the waypoint represents the
    end results of a large logical SOP block (as mentioned above).
On the other hand, a SOP network littered with Waypoint nodes
turn into a nightmare quickly. So –

This SOP introduces additional (manual) maintenance burdens to your SOP network –
    as soon as you start using waypoints, you’ll have to ensure that the geometry on disk matches
    the current state of the upstream network. This can be a source for
    many mistakes.
Use as few instances of this node as possible.

Takes allow to work with lower-quality settings (if possible) and only calculate with higher settings
    when writing the results to disk (e.g. when baking ambient occlusion to per-point colors, the sampling
    quality can be boosted for the disk version only).
of the same input is supported (see the

To quickly build ROP networks of Waypoints
, create a ROP network, then use one of the following buttons in the Tools tab:

Then you can build the ROP network by connecting the generated nodes in the proper order. By
        rendering this ROP network, all your Waypoints will be updated properly.

Substepping is used if more than one evaulated geometry is to be saved for each frame.
    Useful applications:
The waypointed results are to be retimed (especially slow-motion)
Multi-segmented motion blur is desired for rendering

and choose a

        (The
field shows the number of substeps currently set up.)
For properly working substepping the following needs to be set up:
The filename extension should support fractional frame values (see provided presets)

The frame range increment should be set to the appropriate value

Waypoints don’t provide any interpolation of geometry data.

or equivalent
        (TimeBlend qL also supports substeps).
Substeps and the floating point format

is one of the ancient curses of computing in general, whenever an accurate
    representation of real numbers is needed – surprisingly, it can even affect
    simple numeric computations, such as substep counters.
we strongly recommend to always stick to powers-of-2 substep numbers
as they have much less chance to have rounding errors (and hence, missing/doubled cache frames).
All subframe presets are updated accordingly (they offer 2, 4, 8, 16, 32, 64, 128 sub-frames).
There is a special output directory preset called
This preset uses two user-defined variables for specifying the output path:
– A subfolder in the scene file directory.

Having this variable allows relocating the cache folder to another path
        if necessary (e.g. to a faster/local disk, etc.)

This still uses the hip file name in the output path, but it allows saving
        a differently named hip file if necessary.
These variables don’t exist by default and need to be set up manually.
To read more about setting up variables, see the

– except that
        it can store paths with other variables un-expanded.)
If turned on, the Waypoint does nothing (behaves like a plain

node).
        This is 'On' by default and needed to be turned off explicitly once the user performed a
        write-to-disk operation.

Main node state.
        Whenever it’s changed, the node color also gets updated to give more distinct visual feedback.
An inactive waypoint. It just passes through any input geometry as it is.
An active waypoint that reads geometry from disk and feeds it to its output.
The frame range to be used.

Substepping (multiple files per frame) is fully supported by using fractional values
            for the

parameter. Use the preset popup (at the right) to choose a reasonable
            default (but most importantly see the Substepping section above on how to set it up easily).
Settings for the path/name of the output file(s).

The folder, name and extension parts are each represented by a parameter. This makes
        setting them up quick and easy (it’s usually just clicking on one of the preset menu items).

They also come with very reasonable default values (basically you're just have to give the
        Waypoint a meaningful name and that’s it).
Pressing this button will create the directory set up in the

section.
                Note that this also happens automatically before each geometry write, so there’s
                usually no need to do this manually.

Open the output directory in the operating system’s native file manager
                (right now it’s linux-only and launches the Gnome
Pressing this button will delete the entire output folder

.
                Useful for getting rid of large amounts of cached geometry (but make sure the
                folder doesn’t contain anything else important).

The folder to store the output file(s) in. If it doesn’t exist, it will be created before
            writing. By default it’s a subfolder with the name of the Waypoint node.
The output file name. (See the pop-down menu for the most common settings, including

Output file extension (with file numbering for sequences). See the pop-down menu for
            the most regular values.

H11 bgeo format, compatible with other applications such as PartIO.
                Make sure a proper substep preset is chosen if substepping is to be used.

To use named variants, select the appropriate naming preset from the

This is a read-only parameter that returns the variant name specified by the variant number.
            (Try pressing MMB on the parameter label, then pull on the
slider to see the names displayed).

parameter for display purposes, but it can also be used in expressions

This parameter contains the final pathname that is passed to both the geometry writer and reader.

Although it can be edited, it’s recommended to keep the default expression as it is, and use the

This parameter is intended to be used mostly as feedback. Press

on the parameter label to toggle

An action this node should perform when it needs to clean up after itself.

If this node is being deleted, it displays a dialog if it should delete its output directory
                from disk (to avoid wasting disk space with obsolete data).
This will unconditionally delete the output directory –

.
                Although care must be taken, this behaviour has its uses (such as waypointed partial results
                automatically cleaning up after themselves.)
Options to make the geometry data more compact.

These are applied in Pass-Through mode, allowing the differences to be
            inspected by the user.
A list of attribute names to delete before writing.

If enabled, only the first frame will contain the complete geometry when writing sequences.
            The other frames will store point data only (even that is stripped down to
            position and velocity by default – the idea to reduce disk consumption,
            I/O and geometry construction time.)
Do not use it for particles

The path and filename of the geometry file. By default the geometry name is built

The upstream network will be evaluated using the specified Take.
Type of progress indication to use during the write process.

operation as the very first step.

to be reset. This includes DOP Networks, POP SOPs, and other OPs that cache their results.

This is the safest way to render out a simulation, because it starts the simulation from scratch
            and discards any partial simulations you might have done with different parameters.
Nodes like the Cache SOP are not affected by this switch (but see below).
of Cache-like SOP nodes before waypointing.

Although it has to be set up manually, it provides a mechanism to flush memory-caching
            based SOP(s) before waypointing, to ensure up-to-date results.

The following button names are supported:
The pop-down menu provides a few basic presets to work from.

If enabled, the Performance Monitor will be recording during the rendering process,
            and the resulting data will be saved to the file specified.

The comment field of the node is used as a simple message logging area (mostly logging
            rendering start/finish times). This button clears the comment field.

Geometry reading settings (geometry file name is specified in
        the Output File field above – see also
Pressing this button will (re)read the geometry file from disk.

This clamps the geo reader’s frame range (by default to the written range).
            It’s recommended to leave it enabled, especially for substepped setups.
The expression for determining the current frame if

is enabled.
            By default it performs frame range clamping and fractional rounding for
            substeps.

This field’s expression provides the full path to the Waypoint’s internal render output OP.
            It can be useful if this exact path is needed (when rendering from a command shell, for example).

Quick and easy output of substepped file sequences.

By picking a preset, all related parameters will be set up

After such a preset is applied, the number of substeps can be changed by adjusting

parameter (there’s a preset popup menu provided
            there as well).

indicator is also displayed here if multiple

Same as the third combo above, but instead of a single Wedge ROP, it creates copies of the
                same Wedge ROP for each value in the Wedge Range (see below).

This results in a Wedge node for each variant, so every single variant can be rendered
                by calling the corresponding Wedge. This might be convenient for running multiple wedges
                simultaneously on the same machine in batch mode, for example.
Name of the Waypoint SOP parameter that should be

(changed for each wedge).
                The default setting is to work with the Waypoint’s

The range to set up on wedge node(s). The wedge(s) will go through this numeric range
                and render the Waypoint for each value.
Shouldn’t be time-dependent if a single frame is cached

Make sure it works embedded in another asset (although generally it’s not a recommended thing).
      Most problems would be when it tries to changes itself (color, etc).

if checked, it just save the file, don’t ask about it

        (it’s recognized by the render scheduler)
H15 File SOP option to Reader tab
Added other packed-related params to Reader tab
TODO: publish additional H15 File SOP options on Reader tab (e.g. Cache Frames)
Added preset menu for Attributes parameter (with a single element
Added Print Detailed Geometry Info toggle (Writer tab)
Frame Indicator progress type now also provides a datestamp
Minor UI tweaks (file extension preset menu changes)
A more proper implementation of background write process
It’s a toggle now instead of another button
It always saves the current scene without asking (as if the

(so the Scheduler panel can always display
          progress percentage)

The old one seems to have been the culprit of various floating-point inaccuracies
        when used together with substepping (even with power-of-2 substeps).

The function of the old one was to always provide a valid geometry file (even if
        the current frame doesn’t correspond to a substep). Unfortunately it kept adding
        inaccuracies at larger frame numbers.
The new one is safer in terms of

(har har), but will return an error
        or empty geometry if the current frame is not an exact substep.

Best substepping strategy – pick a substep number, and stick to it
            (simulation->file caching->exporting). And pray now and again.

to have presets with power of 2 (1/4, 1/16, 1/64, etc.)
            to avoid problems when caching subframes. They

work better as they can be
            represented better in the floating point format.
Minor UI improvements related to Wedges:

menu button, with an item that lists Wedge ROPs
          (to the console output)
Better error handling (more verbose messages, etc)
In batch mode each Waypoint now prints out its RENDER node path
Fixed typo that broke Fetch/Wedge creation tools
should now work on all platforms (windows, mac)
Added Compression tab (a la FileCache SOP)
Added toolid/toolcount user data creation for newly created nodes.
Consolidated descriptive parm (extra info shown in network view)
Default extension is now uncompressed bgeo sequence
Added support for sub-frame waypointing (multiple files per frame). See the sub-frame support paragraph.
Clear Cache OPs now supports the Reload button on File SOPs.

Waypoints are now created with the appropriate color reflecting their state
        (even if there’s a permanent default preset with a non-default passthru value).
Limitation: node color doesn’t (yet) change when applying a preset.

Removed UI annoyance when deleting a waypoint: now it asks to delete the related directory
        if it actually exists.

Applied a few modifications so Waypoints could be used within assets without problems
        (yet to be tested – post-render auto-reloading of geometry can be a problem).
        For now it’s safest to specify waypoints in assets as editable nodes.

Internal geometry reload is flagged to be triggered at each post-frame,
          so it will refresh even if a sequence is aborted
New: added support for explicitly clear cache-like SOPs with 'Initialize Simulation OPs' toggle in Writer
option (allows auto-deletion of output dir on quit)
Fixed important issue: rendering a waypoint will invoke an automatic file reload.

(The lack of auto-reload was especially annoying for chained Waypoints rendered from a corresponding
            chained ROP/Fetch nodes – with the intermediate results not updating, the entire purpose of ROP
            chaining was defeated.)
Santa brought a ((Create Wedge ROP)) button. :)
More convenient default parameter settings on created Wedge ROPs
Wedge range can now be explicitly specified
Multiple Wedge nodes can now be created (where each is set to
Target ROP network is created if it doesn’t exist
UI: minor layout changes; some pop-up messages turned into status-line feedbacks
Added support for File Merge SOP creation (for loading wedged-seeded geometry).
Created File/FileMerge SOPs are now placed right under the Waypoint node in the network.
Minor UI changes (more accessible render/reload buttons, label changes, etc.)
Bug fix: Points Only for Consecutive Frames now uses the first frame of the render range (instead of frame #1).
Full output file (sequence) path is now constructed from three components (path, name, extension) – all represented with a separate parameter. This results in shorter filename expressions.
Got rid of multiple inputs, added
instead (so there’s still built-in support for writing multiple variants of the same input). Variants can be numeric or textual.
The output directory is created before writing (if it doesn’t exist).
Node state (disabled/enabled) feedback both as node color and in a parameter editor message
Start/end time for the last few render processes are stored (logged) in the node comment field
Option for clamping the time range to the range set up in the Writer tab
Option for writing point data only for all but the first frame

title: Waypoint qL
summary: Marks a point in a SOP network where intermediate (or expensive) results can be saved to disk and re-used.
